speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: SCENE I. Belmont. Avenue to PORTIA'S house.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Enter LORENZO and JESSICA

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: The moon shines bright: in such a night as this,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And they did make no noise, in such a night

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Troilus methinks mounted the Troyan walls

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And sigh'd his soul toward the Grecian tents,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Where Cressid lay that night.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: In such a night

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Did Thisbe fearfully o'ertrip the dew

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And saw the lion's shadow ere himself

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And ran dismay'd away.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: In such a night

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Stood Dido with a willow in her hand

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Upon the wild sea banks and waft her love

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: To come again to Carthage.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: In such a night

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Medea gather'd the enchanted herbs

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: That did renew old AEson.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: In such a night

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Did Jessica steal from the wealthy Jew

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And with an unthrift love did run from Venice

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: As far as Belmont.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: In such a night

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Stealing her soul with many vows of faith

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: And ne'er a true one.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: In such a night

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Did pretty Jessica, like a little shrew,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Slander her love, and he forgave it her.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I would out-night you, did no body come;

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Enter STEPHANO

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: A friend.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: A friend! what friend? your name, I pray you, friend?

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: Stephano is my name; and I bring word

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: My mistress will before the break of day

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: Be here at Belmont; she doth stray about

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: For happy wedlock hours.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Who comes with her?

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: None but a holy hermit and her maid.

speaker: STEPHANO
text_entry: I pray you, is my master yet return'd?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: He is not, nor we have not heard from him.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But go we in, I pray thee, Jessica,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And ceremoniously let us prepare

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Some welcome for the mistress of the house.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter LAUNCELOT

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Sola, sola! wo ha, ho! sola, sola!

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Who calls?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Sola! did you see Master Lorenzo?

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Master Lorenzo, sola, sola!

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Leave hollaing, man: here.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Sola! where? where?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Here.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Tell him there's a post come from my master, with

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: his horn full of good news: my master will be here

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: ere morning.

speaker: LAUNCELOT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Sweet soul, let's in, and there expect their coming.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And yet no matter: why should we go in?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: My friend Stephano, signify, I pray you,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Within the house, your mistress is at hand;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And bring your music forth into the air.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Exit Stephano

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Here will we sit and let the sounds of music

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Creep in our ears: soft stillness and the night

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Become the touches of sweet harmony.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Sit, Jessica. Look how the floor of heaven

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: There's not the smallest orb which thou behold'st

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But in his motion like an angel sings,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Still quiring to the young-eyed cherubins;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Such harmony is in immortal souls;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But whilst this muddy vesture of decay

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter Musicians

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Come, ho! and wake Diana with a hymn!

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And draw her home with music.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Music

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: I am never merry when I hear sweet music.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: The reason is, your spirits are attentive:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: For do but note a wild and wanton herd,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Or race of youthful and unhandled colts,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neighing loud,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Which is the hot condition of their blood;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Or any air of music touch their ears,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: You shall perceive them make a mutual stand,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Their savage eyes turn'd to a modest gaze

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: By the sweet power of music: therefore the poet

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Did feign that Orpheus drew trees, stones and floods;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Since nought so stockish, hard and full of rage,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But music for the time doth change his nature.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: The man that hath no music in himself,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Is fit for treasons, stratagems and spoils;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: The motions of his spirit are dull as night

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: And his affections dark as Erebus:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Let no such man be trusted. Mark the music.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Enter PORTIA and NERISSA

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That light we see is burning in my hall.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How far that little candle throws his beams!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: So shines a good deed in a naughty world.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: When the moon shone, we did not see the candle.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: So doth the greater glory dim the less:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A substitute shines brightly as a king

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Unto the king be by, and then his state

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Empties itself, as doth an inland brook

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Into the main of waters. Music! hark!

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: It is your music, madam, of the house.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nothing is good, I see, without respect:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: When neither is attended, and I think

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The nightingale, if she should sing by day,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: When every goose is cackling, would be thought

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: No better a musician than the wren.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How many things by season season'd are

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To their right praise and true perfection!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Peace, ho! the moon sleeps with Endymion

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And would not be awaked.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Music ceases

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: That is the voice,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Or I am much deceived, of Portia.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: By the bad voice.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Dear lady, welcome home.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: We have been praying for our husbands' healths,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Are they return'd?

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Madam, they are not yet;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But there is come a messenger before,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: To signify their coming.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Go in, Nerissa;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Give order to my servants that they take

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: No note at all of our being absent hence;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nor you, Lorenzo; Jessica, nor you.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A tucket sounds

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Your husband is at hand; I hear his trumpet:

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: We are no tell-tales, madam; fear you not.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: This night methinks is but the daylight sick;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: It looks a little paler: 'tis a day,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Such as the day is when the sun is hid.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter BASSANIO, ANTONIO, GRATIANO, and their followers

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: We should hold day with the Antipodes,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: If you would walk in absence of the sun.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Let me give light, but let me not be light;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For a light wife doth make a heavy husband,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And never be Bassanio so for me:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But God sort all! You are welcome home, my lord.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I thank you, madam. Give welcome to my friend.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: This is the man, this is Antonio,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To whom I am so infinitely bound.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You should in all sense be much bound to him.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For, as I hear, he was much bound for you.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: No more than I am well acquitted of.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Sir, you are very welcome to our house:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: It must appear in other ways than words,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: [To NERISSA]  By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: In faith, I gave it to the judge's clerk:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Would he were gelt that had it, for my part,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Since you do take it, love, so much at heart.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A quarrel, ho, already! what's the matter?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: That she did give me, whose posy was

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: For all the world like cutler's poetry

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Upon  a knife, 'Love me, and leave me not.'

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: What talk you of the posy or the value?

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: You swore to me, when I did give it you,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: That you would wear it till your hour of death

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: And that it should lie with you in your grave:

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: You should have been respective and have kept it.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Gave it a judge's clerk! no, God's my judge,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: The clerk will ne'er wear hair on's face that had it.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: He will, an if he live to be a man.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Ay, if a woman live to be a man.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Now, by this hand, I gave it to a youth,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: A kind of boy, a little scrubbed boy,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: No higher than thyself; the judge's clerk,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: A prating boy, that begg'd it as a fee:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I could not for my heart deny it him.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You were to blame, I must be plain with you,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To part so slightly with your wife's first gift:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I gave my love a ring and made him swear

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Never to part with it; and here he stands;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nor pluck it from his finger, for the wealth

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That the world masters. Now, in faith, Gratiano,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: An 'twere to me, I should be mad at it.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: [Aside]  Why, I were best to cut my left hand off

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And swear I lost the ring defending it.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Unto the judge that begg'd it and indeed

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Deserved it too; and then the boy, his clerk,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: That took some pains in writing, he begg'd mine;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And neither man nor master would take aught

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: But the two rings.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What ring gave you my lord?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Not that, I hope, which you received of me.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: If I could add a lie unto a fault,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I would deny it; but you see my finger

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Hath not the ring upon it; it is gone.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Even so void is your false heart of truth.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: By heaven, I will ne'er come in your bed

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Until I see the ring.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Nor I in yours

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Till I again see mine.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Sweet Portia,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: If you did know to whom I gave the ring,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: If you did know for whom I gave the ring

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And would conceive for what I gave the ring

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And how unwillingly I left the ring,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: When nought would be accepted but the ring,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You would abate the strength of your displeasure.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If you had known the virtue of the ring,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Or half her worthiness that gave the ring,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Or your own honour to contain the ring,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You would not then have parted with the ring.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What man is there so much unreasonable,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If you had pleased to have defended it

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With any terms of zeal, wanted the modesty

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To urge the thing held as a ceremony?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nerissa teaches me what to believe:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I'll die for't but some woman had the ring.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No, by my honour, madam, by my soul,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No woman had it, but a civil doctor,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Which did refuse three thousand ducats of me

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And begg'd the ring; the which I did deny him

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And suffer'd him to go displeased away;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Even he that did uphold the very life

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Of my dear friend. What should I say, sweet lady?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I was enforced to send it after him;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I was beset with shame and courtesy;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: My honour would not let ingratitude

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: So much besmear it. Pardon me, good lady;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: For, by these blessed candles of the night,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Had you been there, I think you would have begg'd

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The ring of me to give the worthy doctor.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Let not that doctor e'er come near my house:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Since he hath got the jewel that I loved,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And that which you did swear to keep for me,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I will become as liberal as you;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I'll not deny him any thing I have,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: No, not my body nor my husband's bed:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Know him I shall, I am well sure of it:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Lie not a night from home; watch me like Argus:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If you do not, if I be left alone,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Now, by mine honour, which is yet mine own,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I'll have that doctor for my bedfellow.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: And I his clerk; therefore be well advised

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: How you do leave me to mine own protection.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Well, do you so; let not me take him, then;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: For if I do, I'll mar the young clerk's pen.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I am the unhappy subject of these quarrels.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Sir, grieve not you; you are welcome notwithstanding.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Portia, forgive me this enforced wrong;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And, in the hearing of these many friends,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Wherein I see myself--

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Mark you but that!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In both my eyes he doubly sees himself;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In each eye, one: swear by your double self,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And there's an oath of credit.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Nay, but hear me:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I never more will break an oath with thee.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I once did lend my body for his wealth;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Which, but for him that had your husband's ring,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Had quite miscarried: I dare be bound again,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: My soul upon the forfeit, that your lord

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Will never more break faith advisedly.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Then you shall be his surety. Give him this

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And bid him keep it better than the other.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Here, Lord Bassanio; swear to keep this ring.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I had it of him: pardon me, Bassanio;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For, by this ring, the doctor lay with me.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: And pardon me, my gentle Gratiano;

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: For that same scrubbed boy, the doctor's clerk,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: In lieu of this last night did lie with me.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Why, this is like the mending of highways

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: In summer, where the ways are fair enough:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Speak not so grossly. You are all amazed:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Here is a letter; read it at your leisure;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: It comes from Padua, from Bellario:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: There you shall find that Portia was the doctor,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nerissa there her clerk: Lorenzo here

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Shall witness I set forth as soon as you

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And even but now return'd; I have not yet

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Enter'd my house. Antonio, you are welcome;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And I have better news in store for you

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Than you expect: unseal this letter soon;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: There you shall find three of your argosies

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Are richly come to harbour suddenly:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You shall not know by what strange accident

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I chanced on this letter.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I am dumb.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Were you the doctor and I knew you not?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Were you the clerk that is to make me cuckold?

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Ay, but the clerk that never means to do it,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Unless he live until he be a man.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Sweet doctor, you shall be my bed-fellow:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: When I am absent, then lie with my wife.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Sweet lady, you have given me life and living;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: For here I read for certain that my ships

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Are safely come to road.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How now, Lorenzo!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: My clerk hath some good comforts too for you.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Ay, and I'll give them him without a fee.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: There do I give to you and Jessica,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: From the rich Jew, a special deed of gift,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: After his death, of all he dies possess'd of.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Fair ladies, you drop manna in the way

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: Of starved people.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: It is almost morning,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And yet I am sure you are not satisfied

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of these events at full. Let us go in;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And charge us there upon inter'gatories,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And we will answer all things faithfully.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Let it be so: the first inter'gatory

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: That my Nerissa shall be sworn on is,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Whether till the next night she had rather stay,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Or go to bed now, being two hours to day:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: But were the day come, I should wish it dark,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: That I were couching with the doctor's clerk.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Well, while I live I'll fear no other thing

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: So sore as keeping safe Nerissa's ring.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Exeunt
